Author: Mark Winch
Title: Dispatch
Excerpt: The revival of Telltale with a solid game.
Paragraph: Dispatch is a narrative-driven game that immediately stands out thanks to its strong identity. It feels like a mix between a video game and a TV show, blending interactivity with the pacing and emotional beats of a serialized narrative. Dispatch is honestly on par with the best of what Telltale has offered in the past, classics like The Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us. For the price, it offers exceptional value and delivers a game that feels fully realized.

The game is full of personality. From the distinctive art direction to the impressive cast, Dispatch brings its world to life. Every character is so interesting, and the writing is sharp, very rarely cheesy. It is somewhat a rom-com, but the overall tone (close to something like the Invincible series) really works.

One thing that absolutely deserves praise is its cast. Every performance feels right; the range and quality of emotions every member of the cast can achieve surprised me. It makes emotional scenes and comedic dialogue work in a way few narrative games manage to achieve. I honestly didn’t expect to hear Joel Haver in my video games, but he ended up being a really good surprise — Waterboy is the best.

The gameplay is also surprisingly sharp. Each mechanic feels tuned to the story beat it supports, giving the player something new to interact with each episode. It is simple but efficient, and it helps break up the narrative flow of the TV structure to engage the player a bit more.

However, the experience isn’t without flaws. The length of certain episodes can feel uneven, and the pacing occasionally suffers from these variations. Overall, the season feels a bit short, leaving you wanting just a few more episodes or deeper exploration in certain storylines.

There is also the matter of player choice. While Dispatch presents several decisions that seem meaningful in the moment, not all of them lead to substantial consequences. Sometimes, choices feel more cosmetic than impactful. It doesn’t ruin the experience, but it does soften the sense of agency in key moments after multiple playthroughs.

Still, these criticisms don’t overshadow what Dispatch does well. For the price, the quality of writing, creativity in gameplay, and overall personality of the adventure easily justify giving it a high score. It delivers an immersive and well-made story that keeps you invested from start to finish.

In summary, Dispatch is a delightful narrative experience that offers great value and memorable moments. Its charm, fun gameplay, impressive cast, and TV show–like structure outweigh its pacing inconsistencies, shorter length, and limited choice impact. If you enjoy character-driven adventures, this one is definitely worth your time.
GoodSummary: On par with Telltale's best narrative games
BadSummary: Overall experience feels a bit short
